Your answer:
What is shading? Please give your definition with mentioning some of its characteristics: when is it used, what is it used for, which elements are important, etc.

What are isolines? Try to think of how can they be created. Does more than one type exist? Try to name them. What do they represent? Which terrain characteristics they show on a map? Can you think of something more?

Location permission is required for this demo.
You did not answer the question. Try selecting an answer.

Dear student, this app was developed for an outdoor exercise for participants of the “Alpine Cartographic Field School.” It covers the topic of terrain representation on maps. There are four main cartographic methods used for it:

1. Contour lines and elevations
 2. Shading
 3. Elevation tints
 4. Hachuring
Your task is to complete all the quiz topics and submit your results.

Save your group’s number (will be assigned by professors) and the names of its members. This info will be submitted along with your results for the evaluation. Additionally, you may also name your group whatever you like :)

Each of the four quiz topics relates to one of the four checkpoints. You can find the checkpoints marked on the hiking route on the map. These locations relate to questions in quiz topics and will help you in answering them.
Complete each of the four topics.

Each checkpoint represents one cartographic method for displaying relief on maps. Once you start a topic, it’s possible to leave and restart it, but the ones competed in the first try are better graded at the end! Otherwise, it wouldn’t be fair, right?

Each topic is like a small quiz with questions; you need to answer correctly to a question to proceed to the next one. There is no previous theoretical input given! Don’t worry; it is not hard if you focus. Just think at loud, discuss and debate with your colleagues in the group to find correct answers. Some questions are related to previous ones, so remembering the previous correct answers will help you.

At the end of each topic, you will have an open question. Here, you have to put in your own words what you have learned about the cartographic method. Use what you have learned in the previous questions to compel a meaningful summary.
After completing all the checkpoints, you may review your answers to the four open questions. If you like, make changes before submitting them.
You will collect points at each question:
+2 points for answering in one attempt,\n+1 point for answering in two attempts,\n+0 points for more than two attempts.
The final score sums points from each of the checkpoints.Try to get a higher score by making meaningful discussions in finding the right answers!
Okay, you answered it all? Congratulations! Press Submit and send your results. (You will need an internet connection for that.)
Developed by Moris Zahtila\nSupervised by Prof. Dirk Burghardt\nTU Dresden. Last revision: 2019.

Elevation tints
Hachuring
Shading
Contour lines
See the example: Click the toolbar button.
Click the toolbar button.
(Rotate the screen 90 degrees to the left to get a North view)
1. What do elevation tints use to show the relief on maps?
2. Look at the example. Do these legends show a classification by elevation tints?
3. Look around you. How many colors you do need to use to represent the surrounding area on a 1:20K map using elevation tints?
4. Why were the previous answers not suitable for elevation tints?
5. How many colors do elevation tints usually use?
6. Look at the example. Find the elevation of the marked point using the information given by elevation tints.
1. Which technique is used to represent rocks and cliffs on maps?
2. Take a careful look at the examples and choose three statements that are valid for the hachuring technique.
3. Look around you and compare the map with what you see. How is hachuring used on the map?\nSelect two statements.
4. Look at the mountain peaks around you. Compare the map with what you see and discuss the hachuring technique used. Use your conclusions in the next question.

DISCUSS:
How was the hachuring made?
Does it show well what you see in reality?
Identify the most prominent parts of the hachuring. Is there a difference in representing steep slopes and rocky cliffs?
Etc.
1. In which ways does shading represent relief on maps?\nMore than one answer may be correct.
2. Look at the example. What is the most important element for relief shading?
4. Since the light source is normally at the NW, the terrain is usually illuminated from:
5. Compare the examples. What may happen if we change the position of the light source for 180 degrees, from the upper left (upper map) to the bottom right (lower map) corner?
3. Look at the map. Try to find the position of the light source used for terrain shading? Compare with what you see around you and with information given by contour lines.
6. Does the terrain shading give enough information for a detailed understanding of the terrain?
7. Carefully check the two example maps and then evaluate the statement:\nConsidering contour lines is important for proper terrain shading.
1. Which three statements are true for contour lines?
2. What are the two further characteristics of contour lines?
3. Evaluate the following statement:\nClosely spaced contour lines indicate a steep slope.
4. Observe the hill where the Südwandhutte is located. Which two statements describe contour lines that would represent that hill on a map?

5. Evaluate the following statement:\nWhile flat areas might best be mapped with a 5-meter contour interval, stepped terrain may have a 20-meter or larger interval. This is why the contour interval is still specified on the legend of a topographic map.
6. Look at the example map. What is the approximate elevation difference between the river valley to the south and Südwandhutte if the equidistance is 20 meters?
7. Why are some contour lines thicker than others?
8. Look at the example. The blue track on the map indicates that:
9. Look at the example. Which slope on the map is the least steep one?
10. Contour lines may indicate hills, mountains, valleys, and:
11. Compare the map example with the landscape in front of you. Are there ridges indicated on the map by contour lines?

Is the choice of colors in elevation tints arbitrary? If not, how should these colors be arranged? Look again around you and argue how many and which colors would you use to represent your surrounding on maps of large and small scales?
What is the purpose of hachuring?\nSelect the statement(s) you consider most relevant.
You will not get points here. Your answers will be saved as your summary of the topic.
What is terrain shading?
Give your definition and mention some of its characteristics: when is it used, what for, which elements are important, etc.
What are contour lines?
Think of how can they be created. Does more than one type exist? Try to name them. What do they represent? Which terrain characteristics they show on a map? Can you think of something more?
Symbols
Lines
Colors
Fonts
Hierarchy of layers
Yes, because they show colors
Yes, because they show vegetation
No, they show vegetation symbolization
No, only some colors of color pallets are shown
1 — green for vegetation
2 — green for vegetation and white for mountain peaks
3 — dark green for woods, light green for meadows, and white for mountain peaks
4 — dark green for woods, light green for meadows, white for mountain peaks, and gray for valley bottoms
I do not agree with any of the answers
It is necessary to use more than four colors
This technique is not used to represent vegetation, but elevation ranges
This technique is only used on small-scale maps (1:1M or smaller)
This technique is only used on large-scale maps (1:5K or larger)
2–3 — For hills and valleys, and sometimes mountains
Min. 5 — Otherwise, there is no sufficient information about relief given on the map
Depends on the number of elevation ranges that have to be differentiated
Any number — Layer tints are only used for aesthetic purpose anyway
1600–1800 m (It is only possible to determine the elevation range with elevation tints)
None of the above
Symbolization
Shading
Hachuring
Combination of contour lines and shading
They are not being shown on maps
Rock hachuring is mostly hand-made.
Rock hachuring would not be used on today\'s maps.
This expensive method can only be produced by specialists.
Representing cliffs and rocks on topographic maps is (still) a very difficult task.
Representing cliffs and rocks on topographic maps can be easily done digitally today.
Rocks are represented with lines.
Dots indicate debris and scree on the surface and are aligned to give a rough idea on the direction of the mass movement.
Rocks and cliffs are indicated with brown–colored areas.
To make the map look like it has more content.
To give more accurate information on elevations.
To show the best locations for alpine climbing.
To show good artistic skills.
To use graphical tricks to give steep rocks depicted on a map equivalent visual importance compared to that observed in nature.
Naturally
Aesthetically
Intuitive
Shading is not a cartographic technique
Quality pencil
Good software
Artistic skills
Light direction
3D base map
Upper-left corner
Upper-right corner
Bottom-left corner
Bottom-right corner
Zenith
Nothing — there are no differences in the terrain between the two map examples.
It gets much harder to read the map.
Terrain inverts — e.g., mountains become depressions, valleys become ridges, etc.
None of mentioned — these two maps show two different locations.
Differences between the two maps are not caused by the positions of light sources.
The light source is at the north
The light source is at the north-west
The light source is at the south-west
The light source is at the south
The light source is at the zenith
The map does not show a shaded terrain, but something else
Terrain shading is self-sufficient on the map.
Terrain shading is a bad visual method.
Terrain shading provides a full understanding of the terrain.
Terrain shading only makes maps look more pretty.
Terrain shading gives only a better understanding (impression) of the terrain.
False — Shaded terrain looks same on both maps.
True — Terrain shading on the top map is not detailed enough and doesn\'t follow contour lines well (e.g., some ribs and hills are missing).
False — Terrain shading on the bottom map is too detailed because it followed contour lines (e.g., too many ribs and hills are shown).
False — Proper terrain shading depends on the map scale only.
Contour lines are never closed polylines like circles.
Concentric circles of contour lines indicate a hilltop, mountain peak, or depression.
Distance between contour lines on the map is proportional to the slope.
Distance between contour lines on the map is not proportional to the slope.
Contour lines are perpendicular to lines of steepest slopes.
Contour lines are never perpendicular to lines of steepest slopes.
They are always unevenly spaced
Connect points of equal elevation
Evenly spaced contour lines indicate a gentle slope
They never cross, split, or intersect — at a cliff, they might merge
True
False
Sometimes
Only if unevenly spaced
Contour lines are not closed polygons.
Contour lines are closed polygons like circles or ovals.
Contour lines are evenly spaced because there are no big differences in slopes.
Contour lines are unevenly spaced because there are big differences in slopes.
True
False
The map does not indicate any valley
There is not enough information available to solve the task
Usually, due to printing malfunctions
To indicate directions of ridges
These are index contours and, therefore, labeled
These are special for never intersecting with other contour lines
Steep terrain
Gentle terrain slopes
Uniform terrain with no visible differences in steepness
Variable terrain with noticeable differences in steepness
Red
Black
Pink
Blue
Ribs
Ridges
Depressions
Plateaus
All of the above
No – Only a valley is indicated
Yes – One ridge from Südwandhütte towards the SW
Yes – Several ridges in different directions
No – Contour lines do not indicate any ridges
